I was reminded on the discussion of @Matteo Capucci (he/him) on the positive bias of that construction that relates permutation representations to linear representations. Consider a finite group, GGG. Then comparing G-SetG\text{-}SetG-Set with G-RepG\text{-}RepG-Rep, the linear representations of the latter are much richer than GGG merely acting on sets.

However, if we're allowed virtual permutations representations, formal differences between GGG-sets, then things become much more comparable. The rig functor from G-SetG\text{-}SetG-Set to G-RepG\text{-}RepG-Rep which derives from forming the free vector space on a set, extends to a ring homomorphism from the Burnside ring (Grothendieck ring of G-SetG\text{-}SetG-Set with addition and multiplication) to the representation ring. And one has to root about to find a GGG for which this map isn't surjective. One reasonably low order case is provided by the direct product of the cyclic group of order 3 with the quaternion group of order 8.

Now anyone whose mathematical education was shaped by @John Baez around the first decade of this millennium will recall a different approach to this problem, namely, groupoidification (which includes an amusing imagined dialogue between William and Georg, standing for Burnside and Frobenius). A pithy summary of what's at stake in the use of spans of groupoids over GGG occurs in this comment by Urs Schreiber.

So now I'm wondering what might be said about any relationship between these two approaches.

As evidence that the virtual approach is not just a trick and comes with a good mathematical pedigree:

The Burnside to representation ring comparison functor is secretly a comparison of the equivariant stable cohomotopy of the point with the equivariant K-theory of the point, ultimately deriving from maps of E∞E_{\infty}E∞​-ring spectra: S=KF1→KC→KU\mathbb{S} = K\mathbb{F}_1 \to K \mathbb{C} \to KUS=KF1​→KC→KU (as explained here).

One thing I feel like mentioning is that when you talk about Rep(G)\mathsf{Rep}(G)Rep(G) and representation rings, you get to specify which field you're working over. People heavily focused on physics would tend to use C\mathbb{C}C, but even if you're committed to characteristic zero it's a lot of fun to look at how you can chop a permutation representation into more irreducible representations when you make the field larger. The symmetric groups SnS_nSn​ are nice in that this effect doesn't happen: all irreducible representations are definable already over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. But for most groups this effect occurs, e.g. the left action of Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 on itself gives a 3-dimensional representation that's irreducible over Q\mathbb{Q}Q, but breaks in two as soon as your field contains exp⁡(2πi/3)\exp(2 \pi i /3)exp(2πi/3).

This is all somewhat orthogonal to your point, but it means I think of the passage from actions of groups on sets to actions of groups on vector spaces as a bit more of a 'continuum' than a yes-no thing (where I'm using 'continuum' in a very non-mathematical sense... I'd say 'spectrum' but that too is ambiguous). The bigger your field, the more power you have to grind up group actions into smaller 'atoms'. Once you hit the algebraic closure of Q\mathbb{Q}Q you're done; going further to C\mathbb{C}C or beyond doesn't help.
This stuff was studied intensively by Brauer, and he showed you're done already when your field contains all roots of unity!

Okay, I checked out Serre's counterexample. I would like to understand it in detail. It's the second exercise here, but it refers back to the previous one:

Serre: Linear representations of finite groups

I'm actually at the stage of wanting to learn everything in this book - earlier it would have been impossible for me to be so interested in representation theory over fields other than C\mathbb{C}C, but after years of dabbling in algebra it now seems interesting... but still intimidating.

[EDIT: actually, looking at the book some more, it looks quite enticing.]

So, we're working over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. Any finite group GGG has a group algebra Q[G]\mathbb{Q}[G]Q[G] that is semisimple, and thus a product of finitely many finite-dimensional simple algebras over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. (I'm going to stop saying "finite-dimensional" now - everything is finite-dimensional.)

Each simple algebra over GGG is isomorphic to a matrix algebra Mn(D)M_n(D)Mn​(D) where DDD is a division algebra over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. Unlike over R\mathbb{R}R, there are tons of division algebras over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. These were classified by our friends Brauer, Noether, Hasse and Albert.

Serre assumes we know how each of the simple algebras that are factors of Q[G]\mathbb{Q}[G]Q[G] corresponds to an irreducible representation of GGG.

I think it goes like this: GGG has a representation on Q[G]\mathbb{Q}[G]Q[G] by left multiplication: this is called the regular representation. Every irreducible representation ρ\rhoρ of GGG appears as a summand of the regular representation, but it may appear repeatedly, say nnn times. In fact it appears with a multiplicity equal to its dimension, so nnn is the dimension of ρ\rhoρ.

There's a canonical way to pick out a subrepresentation ρ~\tilde{\rho}ρ~​ of Q[G]\mathbb{Q}[G]Q[G] that contains all these copies of ρ\rhoρ. This subrepresentation is actually a subalgebra of Q[G]\mathbb{Q}[G]Q[G]. And it's a simple algebra! And every simple algebra that appears as a factor of the semisimple algebra Q[G]\mathbb{Q}[G]Q[G] is of this sort!

Since ρ~\tilde{\rho}ρ~​ is a simple algebra it's isomorphic to a matrix algebra over a division algebra. But we can say more: it's isomorphic to Mn(D)M_n(D)Mn​(D) where nnn is the dimension of ρ\rhoρ and DDD is the algebra of endomorphisms of the representation ρ\rhoρ.

(The algebra of endomorphisms of an irreducible representation is a division algebra DDD, by Schur's lemma. Since ρ~\tilde{\rho}ρ~​ is the sum of nnn copies of ρ\rhoρ, its algebra of endomorpisms is Mn(D)M_n(D)Mn​(D).)

Okay, so now to Serre's example. He takes the quaternion group Q8Q_8Q8​ and embeds it in the quaternions in the obvious way, but he uses the quaternions defined over the rationals, which he calls HQ\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Q}}HQ​ - so it's a 4-dimensional rational vector space. When I say 'quaternions' I'll mean these rational quaternions.

He also embeds Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 in the quaternions in an unspecified way. If we were working over the reals it would be easy for me to see that all such embeddings are related by automorphisms of the quaternions: every nnn th root of unity in the quaternions sits inside some copy of the complex numbers in the quaternions, and all such copies are related by automorphisms of the quaternions.

But we're working over the rationals! To embed Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 in the rational quaternions we need to find a rational quaternion that's a cube root of unity! Are all these related by automorphisms of the rational quaternions? Since Serre blithely tells us to pick one, I bet they must be. But let me think about how we do this. Maybe someone else out there would like to do this too.

Puzzle. Find a nontrivial cube root of 1 in the rational quaternions HQ\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Q}}HQ​.

Answer.

Try (1+i+j+k)/2(1 + i + j + k)/2(1+i+j+k)/2. This has norm 1 and its dot product with the quaternion 1 is 1/2, so it's at a 60 degree angle from the quaternion 1. Thanks to how quaternions work, that means it's sixth power is 1. So it's not the right answer... but if we square it, we'll get a quaternion whose cube is 1.

Having picked a cube root of 1 in the rational quaternions - call it ω\omegaω - we get Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 as a multiplicative subgroup of the quaternions. Serre tells us to let this Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 act by left multiplication and Q8Q_8Q8​ by right multiplication on the rational quaternions. This gives a representation of Z/3×Q8\mathbb{Z}/3 \times Q_8Z/3×Q8​ on HQ\mathbb{H}_\mathbb{Q}HQ​.

He claims this representation is irreducible. I believe that already the representation of Q8Q_8Q8​ on HQ\mathbb{H}_\mathbb{Q}HQ​ is irreducible. If it split as the sum of a 1-dimensional rep and a 3-dimensional rep, we'd have a nonzero quaternion qqq that's fixed by right multiplication by i,j,i, j,i,j, and kkk - impossible, because qi,qjqi, qjqi,qj and qkqkqk are always linearly independent! If it split as the sum of a 2-dimensional rep and a 2-dimensional rep, we'd have a 2d subspace of rational quaternions that's preserved by right multiplication by i,ji, ji,j and kkk - impossible, for the same reason!

So okay: HQ\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Q}}HQ​ is an irreducible representation of G=Z/3×Q8G = \mathbb{Z}/3 \times Q_8G=Z/3×Q8​.

By stuff I said earlier, it must correspond to some simple subalgebra of Q[G]\mathbb{Q}[G]Q[G]. Serre claims this is M2(K)M_2(K)M2​(K) where KKK is the extension of the rationals by a cube root of unity, e.g. K=Q[exp⁡(2πi/3)]K = \mathbb{Q}[\exp(2\pi i /3)]K=Q[exp(2πi/3)].

For this to be true, the irreducible representation HQ\mathbb{H}_\mathbb{Q}HQ​ must show up twice in the regular representation of GGG on Q[G]\mathbb{Q}[G]Q[G], and the endomorphisms of each copy must be KKK.

It would take me some time and/or a burst of cleverness to show this. Clearly the field KKK is related somehow to the cube root of unity ω\omegaω that we picked in HQ\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Q}}HQ​; there is probably some sense in which KKK "is" Q[ω]\mathbb{Q}[\omega]Q[ω].

Let me just leave it as a puzzle to myself (and anyone who wants to help out):

Puzzle. If G=Z/3×Q8G = \mathbb{Z}/3 \times Q_8G=Z/3×Q8​, show that the above irreducible representation of GGG on HQ\mathbb{H}_QHQ​ shows up with multiplicity two in the regular representation of GGG.

(Now I'm confused, because I said each irrep appears in the regular representation with a multiplicity equal to its dimension, but the dimension of HQ\mathbb{H}_\mathbb{Q}HQ​ is 4. I may be making mistakes because I'm used to representation theory over C\mathbb{C}C. While HQ\mathbb{H}_\mathbb{Q}HQ​ has dimension 4 over Q\mathbb{Q}Q, H\mathbb{H}H has dimension 2 over C\mathbb{C}C, and maybe that's the relevant number!)

I thought a bit about the puzzle. Notice that

Q[G]≅Q[Z/3]⊗Q[Q8]\mathbb{Q}[G] \cong \mathbb{Q}[\mathbb{Z/3}] \otimes \mathbb{Q}[Q_8] Q[G]≅Q[Z/3]⊗Q[Q8​]

• Q[Z/3]\mathbb{Q}[\mathbb{Z}/3]Q[Z/3] is the free algebra (over Q\mathbb{Q}Q) on a cube root of unity, so it should be closely related to Q[exp⁡(2πi/3)]\mathbb{Q}[\exp(2 \pi i /3)]Q[exp(2πi/3)]. But it's 3-dimensional over Q\mathbb{Q}Q while Q[exp⁡(2πi/3)]\mathbb{Q}[\exp(2 \pi i /3)]Q[exp(2πi/3)] is just 2-dimensional because exp⁡(2πi/3)\exp(2 \pi i /3)exp(2πi/3) obeys a quadratic equation over Q\mathbb{Q}Q.

  • Q[Q8]\mathbb{Q}[Q_8]Q[Q8​] has a basis of 8 guys obeying the quaternion relations, so it should be closely related to QH\mathbb{Q}_{\mathbb{H}}QH​. But it's 8-dimensional over Q\mathbb{Q}Q while QH\mathbb{Q}_{\mathbb{H}}QH​ is just 4-dimensional because in there 111 and −1-1−1 are linearly dependent, and so are iii and −i-i−i, and so on. It's a semisimple algebra so I'm willing to guess it's just QH⊕QH\mathbb{Q}_{\mathbb{H}} \oplus \mathbb{Q}_{\mathbb{H}}QH​⊕QH​. On the other hand, maybe it's M2(Q[i])M_2(\mathbb{Q}[i])M2​(Q[i]).
All this should eventually let me see why QH\mathbb{Q}_{\mathbb{H}}QH​ shows up with mutiplicity two as a subrepresentation of Q[G]\mathbb{Q}[G]Q[G].

Excellent work being done overnight.

I've been flailing around and seem to have the outlines of proof that since the map from the Burnside ring to the representation ring is surjective for both Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 and Q8Q_8Q8​, this must also be true for G=Z/3×Q8G = \mathbb{Z}/3 \times Q_8G=Z/3×Q8​ (using the fact that Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 is a 3-group - every element has order a power of 3 while Q8\mathbb{Q}_8Q8​ is a 2-group).

This contradicts what Serre says, so there must be a flaw, and perhaps the flaw is here:

I feel, but have not proved, that every subgroup H⊆Z/3×Q8H \subseteq \mathbb{Z}/3 \times Q_8H⊆Z/3×Q8​ is of the form H1×H2H_1 \times H_2H1​×H2​ where H1H_1H1​ is a subgroup of Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 and H2H_2H2​ is a subgroup of Q8Q_8Q8​. Then, I feel that when this condition holds - every subgroup of a product G1×G2G_1 \times G_2G1​×G2​ is a product of a subgroup H1⊆G1H_1 \subseteq G_1H1​⊆G1​ and a subgroup H2⊆G2H_2 \subseteq G_2H2​⊆G2​ - we have

where BBB means 'Burnside ring'.

I have an argument that representation rings of finite groups always obey this law:

R(G1×G2)≅R(G1)⊗R(G2) R(G_1 \times G_2) \cong R(G_1) \otimes R(G_2) R(G1​×G2​)≅R(G1​)⊗R(G2​)

Thus, if we have

B(G1)≅R(G1) B(G_1) \cong R(G_1) B(G1​)≅R(G1​) and B(G2)≅R(G2)B(G_2) \cong R(G_2) B(G2​)≅R(G2​)

we get

But this would mean Serre's counterexample

B(Z/3×Q8)≆R(Z/3×Q8) B(\mathbb{Z}/3 \times Q_8) \ncong R(\mathbb{Z}/3 \times Q_8) B(Z/3×Q8​)≆R(Z/3×Q8​)

But if that were true, Serre would have used one of these simpler counterexamples! (Proof by psychology.)

So we get a contradiction.

Conclusion: I should examine the various things I "feel" are true, and look for one to be false. I'll probably cheat and read Serre's book to see if he talks about representation rings or Burnside rings of products of groups.

Meanwhile I've almost worked out the representation ring and Burnside ring of Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 and Q8Q_8Q8​, which was a lot of fun, but there's not much point in reporting on that until I straighten out my confusion.

Well, I can't resist saying a little. I 'cheated' and used Groupprops to read about subgroups of the quaternion group Q8Q_8Q8​, and was delighted to learn that all 6 of its subgroups are normal! Three of them H1,H2,H3H_1, H_2, H_3H1​,H2​,H3​ have 4 elements, so they not only give an action of Q8Q_8Q8​ on a 2-element set Q8/HiQ_8/H_iQ8​/Hi​ but also a 1-dimensional rational representation Q8→Q8/H≅Z/2↪Q∗Q_8 \to Q_8/H \cong \mathbb{Z}/2 \hookrightarrow \mathbb{Q}^\ast Q8​→Q8​/H≅Z/2↪Q∗. I haven't studied the quaternion group much, but given how much I've studied the quaternions all these facts are instant delights, like eating salt peanuts.

Okay, this feeling seems to be correct: someone on Math Stackexchange says all subgroups of a product of groups are products of subgroups iff the two groups have no non-trivial common subquotient. This will be true when one is a p-group and the other is a q-group for distinct primes p and q, for simple numerical reasons.

I haven't gone ahead and used Serre's further hints on how to solve his exercise, and soon I should. But I see one thing: even if we have R(G)≅B(G)R(G) \cong B(G)R(G)≅B(G) for G=Z/3×Q8G = \mathbb{Z}/3 \times Q_8G=Z/3×Q8​ as my perhaps flawed argument shows, that doesn't imply the canonical map from B(G)B(G)B(G) to R(G)R(G)R(G) is an isomorphism! And I feel like boring everyone and talking a bit about the representation ring and the Burnside ring of Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 and Q8Q_8Q8​, because it's good to have some concrete knowledge of a situation before theorizing, and I want to write this stuff down before I forget it.

For Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3:

  1. We have two irreducible representations over Q\mathbb{Q}Q: the 1d trivial representation R1R_1R1​ and a 2d representation R2R_2R2​ where the generator of Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 turns the plane around a 1/3 turn. We have to choose a basis intelligently to define the latter rep over the rationals! But we can do it.

Here we see the irreps are not occuring in the regular rep with a multiplicity equal to their dimension - apparently that's only true over an algebraically closed field. Each of these reps occurs with multiplicity one in the regular rep.

  1. We have two transitive actions on finite sets: the trivial action A1A_1A1​ and the left action of Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 on itself, say A3A_3A3​.

So, the map B(Z/3)→R(Z/3)B(\mathbb{Z}/3) \to R(\mathbb{Z}/3)B(Z/3)→R(Z/3) is an isomorphism, doing this:

A1→R1A_1 \to R_1A1​→R1​

A3→R1⊕R2A_3 \to R_1 \oplus R_2A3​→R1​⊕R2​.

(The map from the Burnside ring to the representation ring is apparently always an isomorphism for cyclic groups.)

For Q8Q_8Q8​:

  1. We seem to have 5 irreducible representation of Q8Q_8Q8​ over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. There's the 1d trivial representation R1R_1R1​. There are three nontrivial 1d representations, say Ri,Rj,RkR_i, R_j, R_kRi​,Rj​,Rk​. In RiR_iRi​, for example, ±i∈Q8\pm i \in Q_8±i∈Q8​ acts as the identity while ±j\pm j±j and ±k\pm k±k act as −1-1−1. The other two are analogous. There's also a 4d representation, say R4R_4R4​, where we think of the quaternion group as sitting inside the quaternions in the obvious way, and let them act by left multiplication.

Note that the dimensions of these irreps add up to 1+1+1+1+4 = 8, making it plausible that the regular rep breaks up as a sum of these irreps, each appearing with multiplicity one.

  1. We have 6 transitive actions of Q8Q_8Q8​ on finite sets, corresponding to the 5 subgroups of Q8Q_8Q8​, which happen to all be normal. There's the trivial action, say A1A_1A1​. There are three actions on 2-element sets, say Ai,Aj,AkA_i, A_j, A_kAi​,Aj​,Ak​, coming from three 4-element normal subgroups. For example AiA_iAi​ is the action on Q8Q_8Q8​ on Q8/{1,i,−1,−i}≅Z/2Q_8/\{1, i , -1, -i \} \cong \mathbb{Z}/2Q8​/{1,i,−1,−i}≅Z/2. The other two are analogous. There's an action A4A_4A4​ of Q8Q_8Q8​ on a 4-element set: in this Q8Q_8Q8​ acts on Q8Q_8Q8​ modulo its center: Q8/{±1}Q_8/\{\pm 1\}Q8​/{±1} is the Klein 4-group. And there's the action A8A_8A8​ of Q8Q_8Q8​ on an 8-element set, namely itself.

It looks like the map from the Burnside ring to the representation ring does this:

A1↦R1A_1 \mapsto R_1A1​↦R1​

Ai↦Ri⊕R1,Aj↦Rj⊕R1,Ak↦Rk⊕R1A_i \mapsto R_i \oplus R_1 , \quad A_j \mapsto R_j \oplus R_1, \quad A_k \mapsto R_k \oplus R_1Ai​↦Ri​⊕R1​,Aj​↦Rj​⊕R1​,Ak​↦Rk​⊕R1​

A4↦Ri⊕Rj⊕Rk⊕R1A_4 \mapsto R_i \oplus R_j \oplus R_k \oplus R_1 A4​↦Ri​⊕Rj​⊕Rk​⊕R1​ (just guessing)

A8↦R4⊕R4A_8 \mapsto R_4 \oplus R_4 A8​↦R4​⊕R4​ (just guessing)

If so, this seems to be a surjection but not an isomorphism, since it's mapping a 6-dimensional ring to a 5-dimensional one. Apparently the map from the Burnside ring to the representation ring is already surjective for p-groups (such as Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 and Q8Q_8Q8​). The nLab says:

The proof of surjectivity for ppp-primary groups is due to Segal 72. (As Segal remarks on his first page, it may also be deduced from Feit 67 (14.3). See also Ritter 72.) The proof is recalled as tom Dieck 79, Theorem 4.4.1.

So now I can clearly see a flaw in my sketchy argument: I was arguing that if the Burnside ring and representation ring were isomorphic for a ppp-group G1G_1G1​ and a qqq-group G2G_2G2​ where ppp and qqq were distinct primes, then they'd also be isomorphic for G1×G2G_1 \times G_2G1​×G2​. But we're already seeing they're not isomorphic for Q8Q_8Q8​! :face_with_spiral_eyes: So I was completely missing the point. The point is that the maps from Burnside ring to representation rings

B(Gi)→R(Gi) B(G_i) \to R(G_i) B(Gi​)→R(Gi​)

are surjective for two groups G1G_1G1​ and G2G_2G2​, yet apparently not for their product G1×G2G_1 \times G_2G1​×G2​.

I should now follow Serre's hints, but I found it very fun and enlightening to work out the map from Burnside to representation ring for Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 and Q8Q_8Q8​. This is one of those things that's more fun to do than to read, I imagine, but the point is: in both these cases the representation ring feels similar to the Burnside ring in a bunch of tantalizing ways that are hard to formalize. I imagine that for a 'typical' group the relationship is less strong.

I also love how Artin got into his theorem on induced characters by trying to understand L-functions (which is something I'm also trying to understand).

Yes, Artin introduced a kind of L-function that arises from a finite-dimensional representation of the Galois group of a number field, now called an [[Artin L-function]]. His induction theorem implied that any such L-function is a product of rational powers of L-functions coming from 1-dimensional representations of cyclic subgroups of that Galois group. This let him show that some integer power of the Artin L-function extends to a meromorphic function on the complex plane.

Artin did this in 1927. Later, in 1947, Brauer proved his induction theorem, which implies that any Artin L-function is a product of integer powers of L-functions coming from 1-dimensional representations of elementary subgroups of that Galois group. This implies that any Artin L-function extends to a meromorphic function on the complex plane.

So in this example it seems that Brauer's induction theorem is just better - it gives a stronger result. The rational powers above become integer powers because every element of the representation ring of the Galois group is a rational linear combination of characters of 1-dimensional representations induced from cyclic subgroups, but an integer linear combination of characters of 1-dimensional representations induced from elementary subgroups. I don't understand how Brauer (or whoever) got around the downside, which is that elementary subgroups aren't abelian.

To give a bit of the flavor, here's the start:

Emil Artin spent the first 15 years of his career in Hamburg. Andre Weil characterized
this period of Artin's career as a "love affair with the zeta function". Claude Chevalley, in his obituary of Artin, pointed out that Artin's use of zeta functions was to discover exact algebraic facts as opposed to estimates or approximate evaluations. In particular, it seems clear to me that during this period Artin was quite interested in using the Artin L-functions as a tool for finding a non-abelian class field theory, expressed as the desire to extend results from relative abelian extensions to general extensions of number fields.

"Nonabelian class field theory" is now the topic of the "Langlands program".

Since Artin was the expert on abelian class field theory (culminating in Artin reciprocity), it's natural that when he tackled L-functions coming from representations of nonabelian Galois groups, he tried to break them down into L-functions coming from representation of abelian subgroups... leading him to prove the Artin induction theorem, a result in representation theory that doesn't even mention L-functions. Brauer's result is a lot subtler, and it brings in nonabelian subgroups, namely "elementary" subgroups.

There may be some ways in which Artin's induction theorem is "better" - leads to more powerful consequences - because it only involves cyclic subgroups. I don't think I've seen them! So far, its main advantage is that the proof is much easier, so by now I completely understand it.
